text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
MATERIAL CHANGES

IRM 11.3.7.1 - Revised title to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in this subsection. Included important information to conform to the new internal and management control standards under the following titles:
a. IRM
, Background - Added information about the background of policies pertaining Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations. Information from prior section
Background was incorporated into this section. b. IRM
, Authority - Added legal authorities governing Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations. c. IRM
, Roles and Responsibilities - This IRM is applicable for all IRS employees to help comply with Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations. d. IRM
, Deﬁnitions/Acronyms - Compiled a list of frequently used terms and acronyms and their deﬁnitions regarding Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations. e. IRM
, Related Resources - Added related resources applicable to the Freedom of Information Act Reading Room Operations.
Removed references to the physical reading room throughout this IRM, since there is no longer a physical reading room, and replaced with the phrase “Electronic” Reading Room, where applicable.
Added new (9) to IRM 11.3.7.1.1, Background, to capture information regarding public inspection amended in the FOIA Improvement Act of 2016.
(1) from IRM 11.3.7.5.1 since the Form 990, Return Organization Exempt From Income is no longer available through the Freedom of Information Act Reading Room.
Removed (2) from IRM 11.3.7.5.2 and IRM 11.3.7.5.3 since Form 1023, Form 1024, Form 8871 Form 8872 are no longer available through the Freedom of Information Act Reading Room.
Removed the second sentence from the Note in IRM 11.3.7.5.4(1) since public inspection of these Forms are no longer available in the Freedom of Information Act Reading Room.

Removed (1) from IRM 11.3.7.7 since the physical reading room is no longer available for public inspection of “Public Comments”. Also clariﬁed the procedure in (3) of this section to indicate with IRS Counsel is needed to request access to these “Public Comments”.
All Operating Divisions and Functions.
The Disclosure and Privacy Knowledge Base can be found at: https://portal.ds.irsnet.gov/sites/vl003/ pages/default.aspx.
Program Scope and Objectives
of Information Act Reading Room Operations 11.3.7

) Purpose: This IRM provides an introduction to the Freedom of Information (FOIA) Reading Room Operations and provides a general overview of every and IRS employee’s responsibility to protect conﬁdentiality of records and tion entrusted to the IRS, while balancing the expectation of openness and transparency in government. (
) Audience: These procedures and guidance apply to all IRS employees and contractors. (
) Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy. (
) Program Owner: The GLDS office, under Privacy, Governmental Liaison and Disclosure (PGLD) is the program office responsible for oversight of the Ser- vicewide Disclosure policy. (

) All IRS Business Units may have a responsibility for making their records available in the Electronic FOIA Reading Room. Any posting of agency to the Electronic Reading Room on IRS.gov will be made in coordination the Senior Disclosure Analyst over the FOIA program. (
) The Freedom of Information Act, (FOIA)
USC §
, as amended provides public access to records and information maintained by Federal agencies. (
) Subsection (a)(

) of the FOIA requires agencies to publish certain relating to the transaction of agency business in the Federal Register, including: a. Descriptions of agency organizations, functions, and procedures b. Substantive agency rules and c. Statements of general agency policy (
) Subsection (a)(

) of the FOIA requires agencies to make available for public inspection and copying: a. Final opinions, including concurring and dissenting opinions, as well as orders, made in the adjudication of cases b. Those statements of policy and interpretations which have been by the agency and are not published in the Federal Register (e.g., revenue rulings, Coordinated Issue Papers, Actions on Decisions, ﬁeld rectives) c. Administrative staff manuals and instructions to staff that affect a of the public (e.g., IRM, Interim Guidance, etc.) (
) In
, subsection (a)(

) was amended to require agencies to include in reading room any records processed and disclosed in response to a FOIA request which “the agency determines have become or are likely to become the subject of subsequent requests for substantially the same records” under USC §

)(D). The Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and guards (GLDS), makes this determination. Note: Based on guidance from the Department of Justice, while records placed reading rooms under subsection (a)(
) cannot ordinarily be the subject of regular FOIA requests under subsection (a)(
), this rule does not apply to records that are in the Electronic Reading Room because they have been requested frequently. Internal Revenue Manual
Policy Owner: The Disclosure office, under Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safeguards (GLDS) is responsible for oversight of Disclosure policy.
The Freedom of Information Act, (FOIA) 5 USC §552, as amended provides for public access to records and information maintained by Federal agencies.
of the public (e.g., IRM, Interim Guidance, etc.) In

) was amended to require agencies to include in their reading room any records processed and disclosed in response to a FOIA request which “the agency determines have become or are likely to become the subject of subsequent requests for substantially the same records” under
USC §
)(D). The Director, Governmental Liaison, Disclosure and Safe- guards (GLDS), makes this determination.
Based on guidance from the Department of Justice, while records placed in reading rooms under subsection (a)(
) cannot ordinarily be the subject of regular FOIA requests under subsection (a)(
), this rule does not apply to records that are in the Electronic Reading Room because they have been requested frequently.

b. Exempt and political organization information subject to public under IRC §

This IRM is used by all IRS employees to help comply with the disclosure pro

visions of the Freedom of Information Act and the IRS FOIA regulations on public inspection of agency records. It also provides guidance to employees on IRS records required to be made available for public inspection and copying and the requirement to make certain records electronically available.

) The FOIA,
USC §

), requires proactive electronic disclosure of certain IRS records, among which are ″administrative staff manuals and in- structions to staff that affect a member of the public.″ For any record listed in FOIA subsections (a)(
)(A) - (E) created by the IRS on or after November

, the FOIA now requires that it be made available electronically (Electronic FOIA or E-FOIA). The IRS achieves this electronic availability through the Electronic Reading Room (ERR). Proactive disclosure means the public must have direct access to the records without having to ﬁle a formal request. IRS complies with this requirement by making instructions to staff and other records meeting the proactive disclosure requirement available through its Electronic Reading Room (ERR), unless the records or portions of the records are exempt from disclosure under the FOIA,
USC §
(b). See also IRM
). Note: IRS removes information from records intended for publication that is exempt

Note: IRS removes information from records intended for publication that is exempt from disclosure under the FOIA and after full and deliberate consideration of the institutional, commercial and personal privacy interests that could be im-

Disclosure of Official plicated by disclosure of the information. Content authors propose an “Official Use Only” (OUO) marking for the content and collaborate with the Disclosure Office to ensure compliance with applicable disclosure laws and policy guidelines. An official in the content author’s business unit with delegated authority under Delegation Order
, found in IRM
, approves and authorizes the designation. IRS withholds from disclosure records or portions of records marked OUO. (

) IRS uses the IRM as the primary repository of instructions to staff. It also interim guidance to issue instructions to staff to supplement the IRM IRM publications. The proactive disclosure requirements of the FOIA extend all instructions to staff affecting a member of the public regardless of form or format. Organizations that deliver procedural instructions outside of the IRM must still comply with the proactive disclosure requirements of the FOIA. IRM

, IRM
, and IRM

describe the procedures and protocols to follow for creating, updating and clearing IRMs and other Internal Management Documents (IMDs) for publication. Media & Publications posts cleared and approved IRMs to the ERR page on IRS.gov as part of the publishing (
) Servicewide Policy, Directives and Electronic Research (SPDER) posts recently issued Policy Statements and Servicewide Delegation Orders to the ERR on IRS.gov. See IRM
and IRM

) The program owner is responsible for ensuring the proper posting of other structions to staff meeting E-FOIA criteria to the ERR web page, such as interim guidance memoranda and Servicewide Electronic Research Program IRM Procedural Updates (SERP IPUs). See IRM
for procedures related to proactive disclosure of interim guidance, including SERP IPUs. (

) A web-based tool, the E-FOIA Decision Tool, is available to assist authors to determine whether particular instructions meet E-FOIA criteria and require posting in the Electronic Reading Room on IRS.gov. (
) When uncertain if E-FOIA applies to interim guidance or unsure about other procedural records that may meet E-FOIA requirements, IMD authors may consult their Disclosure Technical Liaison. (

) IMDs meet FOIA guidelines requiring proactive electronic disclosure and IRS must post them to the Electronic Reading Room (ERR) on IRS.gov when: a. the guidance is procedural and communicates direction, guidelines, or standards to employees for the performance of their assigned duties, b. the guidance affects how a member of the public ﬁles, pays, complies their tax requirements, or interacts with the Service, and c. the guidance is not exempt from disclosure under
USC §
(b). See IRM
, Disclosure Exemptions for Instructions to Staff. (
) If the document restates procedures already available in full on the ERR on IRS.gov, then it is not necessary to post the document on the ERR. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

plicated by disclosure of the information. Content authors propose an “Official Use Only” (OUO) marking for the content and collaborate with the Disclosure Office to ensure compliance with applicable disclosure laws and policy guidelines. An official in the content author’s business unit with delegated authority under Delegation Order 11-1, found in IRM 1.2.49.2, approves and authorizes the designation. IRS withholds from disclosure any records or portions of records marked OUO.

IRS uses the IRM as the primary repository of instructions to staff. It also uses interim guidance to issue instructions to staff to supplement the IRM between IRM publications. The proactive disclosure requirements of the FOIA extend to all instructions to staff affecting a member of the public regardless of form or format. Organizations that deliver procedural instructions outside of the IRM must still comply with the proactive disclosure requirements of the FOIA. See IRM
and IRM

) When instructions to staff meet the proactive electronic disclosure require- ments under the FOIA,
USC §
)(C), IRS may still withhold in full part when two conditions apply. First, one of the nine FOIA exemptions Staff lished in subsection (b)(

) must apply, and further, having met one of the exemptions, there must be full and deliberate consideration of the commercial and personal privacy interests that could be implicated by sure of the information. (
) Instructions to staff should rarely, if ever, contain content that affects privacy interests and of the nine exemptions, generally only
USC §
)(E) applies to instructions to staff. For content to meet exemption (b)(

)(E), there must be a reasonable expectation of harm to IRS business interests resulting from the content’s disclosure. This exemption applies to enforcement materials where disclosure could reasonably be expected to circumvention of the law. IRS designates such content OUO and the record not published if the entire record meets the exemption. If only a portion of record is OUO, that segment is removed prior to publication. (

) If internal management documents contain OUO information and non-OUO information, the OUO information is redacted (removed) and the remaining non-OUO content is accessible to the public, unless the remaining content meaningless. See IRM
, Official Use Only. Note: OUO content must be properly marked by the author, reviewed by the of Disclosure and approved by an official under Delegation Order

provides for public inspection of written determinations, private letter rulings, technical advice memoranda, determination letters, Chief Counsel advice. See IRM
, Disclosure of Written for procedures for the indexing, ﬁling, and viewing of written determinations the Electronic Freedom of Information Act Reading Room. (

) These written determinations are indexed by release number and Uniform Issue List (UIL) Code. The Uniform Issue List is an index of issues based Internal Revenue Code sections. Written determinations issued after
(for Chief Counsel advice) and January
(for letter rulings and technical advice) are posted on the IRS website by Release Number or by Code Section. (
) Each written determination is coded with a nine digit identiﬁcation number (seven digits for written determinations issued before
). Requesters seeking copies of the written determinations are encouraged to make their requests by referencing the identiﬁcation number. (

When instructions to staff meet the proactive electronic disclosure require- ments under the FOIA, 5 USC §552(a)(2)(C), IRS may still withhold in full or part when two conditions apply. First, one of the nine FOIA exemptions estab- lished in subsection (b)(3) must apply, and further, having met one of the exemptions, there must be full and deliberate consideration of the institutional, commercial and personal privacy interests that could be implicated by disclo- sure of the information.

If internal management documents contain OUO information and non-OUO information, the OUO information is redacted (removed) and the remaining non-OUO content is accessible to the public, unless the remaining content is meaningless. See IRM 11.3.12.3.2, Official Use Only.

, as amended, provides the statutory authority for making certain Employee Plan material available to the public. These materials include cations and supporting documents, and any IRS letter issued with regard to the qualiﬁcation of a pension, proﬁt sharing, or stock bonus plan, individual tirement account, or individual retirement annuity, or with respect to the exemption from tax of such plan or account.
